columns.text:
In this scenario, we need to identify the values that we will substitute to the formula for NPV to get the best-case and the worst-case. The NPV or the net present value is a numerical measure of the cashflow, both in and out, of the project. 

This problem asks us to do a scenario analysis where we will look at the best case and worst case scenarios for the values of the project.

For the **best-case scenario**, we first need to solve for the value of the initial cost. Since this is the best-case scenario, we want our value to be $10\%$ lower than the actual value. This means that we need to multiply it by $0.90$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Initial cost}_{\text{best}}&=\$786,000 \times 0.90\\[15 pt]
&=\$707,400
\end{aligned}$$

Now we need to solve for the value of the cashflow. To solve the cashflow, we will use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present cashflow}&=\text{OCF} \times(1-\text{T})+(\text{T} \times \text{D})
\end{aligned}$$

Since we know that $\text{OCF}=(\text{P}-\text{v})\times \text{Q}-\text{FC}$, we can substitute it to the formula giving us:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present cashflow}&=[(\text{P}-\text{v})\times \text{Q}-\text{FC}] \times(1-\text{T})+(\text{T} \times \text{D})
\end{aligned}$$

Where,

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{P}&=\text{Price per unit}\\
\text{v}&=\text{Variable cost per unit}\\
\text{Q}&=\text{Quantity}\\
\text{FC}&=\text{Fixed costs}\\T&=\text{Tax rate}\\
\text{D}&=\text{Depreciation}
\end{aligned}$$

Since we are solving for the best-case, we will solve for $+10\%$ of the price per unit and quantity while computing for $-10\%$ of the variable cost and the fixed cost.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{P}_{\text{best}}&=\$48 \times 1.10\\[15 pt]
&=\$52.80\\[15 pt]
\text{Q}_{\text{best}}&=35793 \times 1.10\\[15 pt]
&=39372\\[15 pt]
\text{v}_{\text{best}}&=\$25 \times 0.90\\[15 pt]
&=\$22.50\\[15 pt]
\text{FC}_{\text{best}}&=\$725,000 \times 0.90\\[15 pt]
&=\$642,500
\end{aligned}$$

Substitute these values to the formula for present cashflow and we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present cashflow}&=[(\$52.80-\$22.50)\times 39372-\$642,500]\\
&\times(1-0.22)+(0.22\times \$98,250)\\[15 pt]
&=\$550,471.60 \times0.78+\$21,615\\[15 pt]
&=\$429,367.85 + \$21,615\\[15 pt]
&=\$450,982.85
\end{aligned}$$

With an expected $10$ per cent return in $8$ years, we can use an annuity table to find the factor which is $4.4873$. This factor will be multiplied to the present cashflow to get the NPV

Substituting the values to get the $\text{NPV}_{\text{best}}$:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}_{\text{best}}&=-\$707,400+\$450,982.85 \times 4.4873\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,316,295.34
\end{aligned}$$

The best-case NPV is $\$1,316,295.34$

For the worst-case, we will simply do the opposite of what we did in the best case.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Initial cost}_{\text{worst}}&=\$786,000 \times 1.10\\[15 pt]
&=\$864,600\\[15 pt]
\text{P}_{\text{worst}}&=\$48 \times 0.90\\[15 pt]
&=\$43.20\\[15 pt]
\text{Q}_{\text{worst}}&=35793 \times 0.90\\[15 pt]
&=32214\\[15 pt]
\text{v}_{\text{worst}}&=\$25 \times 1.10\\[15 pt]
&=\$27.50\\[15 pt]
\text{FC}_{\text{worst}}&=\$725,000 \times 1.10\\[15 pt]
&=\$797,500
\end{aligned}$$

Substitute these values to the formula for present cashflow and we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present cashflow}&=[(\$43.20-\$27.50)\times 32214-\$797,500]\\
&\times(1-0.22)+(0.22\times \$98,250)\\[15 pt]
&=-\$291,740.20\times0.78+\$21,615\\[15 pt]
&=-\$227557.36+ \$21,615\\[15 pt]
&=-\$205,942.36
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values to get the $NPV_{\text{worst}}$:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}_{\text{worst}}&=-\$864,600-\$205,942.36\times 4.4873\\[15 pt]
&=-\$1,788,725.15
\end{aligned}$$

The worst-case NPV is $-\$1,788,725.15$
